summary: This document is a chronological log of psychological observations and suicide risk assessments for Jeffrey Epstein while he was in custody at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, from his arrival in July 2019 until his death in August 2019. It details his mental state, complaints about confinement, interactions with staff and his cellmate, and the mysterious incident on July 23, 2019, where a string was found around his neck.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the psychological observation log. Document details his daily activities, mental state, complaints about prison conditions, interactions with staff and his cellmate, and the events leading up to his death.

persons.name: Dr.
persons.context: The author of the observation log, conducting intake screenings, suicide risk assessments, and regular psychological check-ins with Epstein.

connections.description: Clinical relationship where Dr. is responsible for monitoring Epstein's mental health and suicide risk while in custody.
Epstein shared a cell with this individual in the SHU. Epstein later claimed this cellmate was agitated, called him a pedophile, and he feared the cellmate tried to kill him.
Epstein was meeting with this attorney during legal visits. The attorney was present when Epstein mocked Dr. about being placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Arrives in General Population
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrives at the Metropolitan Correctional Center and is initially placed in General Population (GP).

events.title: Intake Screening and Placement on Psychological Observation
events.description: Dr. conducts an intake screening. Epstein is placed on psychological observation as a precaution pending a Suicide Risk Assessment (SRA).

events.title: First Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. conducts a Suicide Risk Assessment. Epstein denies suicidality, is future-oriented, and wants to speak with his lawyer. Recommended to remain on psychological observation.

events.title: String Incident and Placement on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is placed on Suicide Watch (SW) after a string is found loosely hanging from around his neck. He claims not to remember how it happened and alternatively suggests his cellmate may have been involved.

events.title: Post-Suicide Watch Report and Bail Denial
events.description: Dr. follows up. Epstein reports his cellmate was agitated, called him a pedophile, and he fears returning to the cell. He was recently denied bail. He adamantly denies suicidality.

events.title: Court-Requested Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A IIIMSRA is conducted after the court sent a 'suicidal tendencies' form. Epstein again denies suicidality, citing his Jewish faith and his desire to fight his case.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found unresponsive and hanging in his SHU cell at 6:30 a.m., ten days after being removed from constant observation.

keyFacts: Epstein was placed on psychological observation and later suicide watch as a precaution, despite repeatedly and adamantly denying any suicidal thoughts or intent.

On July 23, 2019, a string was found loosely tied around Epstein's neck. He claimed no memory of the event and suggested his cellmate, who had become agitated and called him a pedophile, may have been responsible.
Epstein expressed numerous complaints about prison conditions, including noise in the SHU, lack of phone calls, recreation, preferred medication (Colace), and his orange uniform.
Epstein was removed from constant psychological observation status on July 30, 2019.
Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his SHU cell on the morning of August 10, 2019.
